        <description><![CDATA[<p>Use your knowledge to make unique creations using our laser cutters, vinyl cutters, 3D printers and milling machine. Staff will be available to provide limited assistance in using the design software and machines. We highly recommend taking one of our workshops to learn the basics of the machines prior to attending Open Shop.<span></span></p>]]></description>

        <title>NCLEX-Registered Nurses Test Prep</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/f94fa661fc65a2f6ec15bb122266dc29/p2pu-logo.jpg" alt="" style="float: right; margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px;"></p><p>Prepare for the National Council Licensing Examination for Registered Nurses (NCLEX-RN) with content developed specifically for nursing students getting ready for the test.<span></span><span></span><span></span><span></span></p><p>In <a href="http://www.knightfoundation.org/grants/201550344/" target="_blank">partnership</a> with <a href="https://p2pu.org/en/" target="_blank">Peer 2 Peer University</a>, we're hosting study groups for learners who want to complete online courses together, in-person at the library. These are free, peer-supported courses designed to be taken by anybody.</p><p>Learn more about <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/news/join-a-study-group-and-take-an-online-course">our study groups for online courses</a>.</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>A Conversation with Mary Schmich</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Columnist Mary Schmich captivates readers with poignant observations on everything from biting snowstorms to corrupt politicians. She has been a reporter for the Chicago Tribune since 1992. She has devoted columns to the Near North neighborhood and our library. In 2012, she was awarded a Pulitzer Prize for Commentary recognizing 2011 work for the Tribune and her "wide range of down-to-earth columns that reflect the character and capture the culture of Chicago."</p><p>Sponsored by the Near North Library Friends Association.</p><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme "Chicago: The City That Gives."<span></span></p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/5602e0170a8ecbcc3205a0cb</link>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: &quot;In The Game&quot;</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/a6cc0dae4cbfe62ec006e193d1b07d64/inthegame-fence-resized.jpg" alt="" style="margin: auto; display: block;">Join us for a screening of the new documentary film from Kartemquin Films, <a href="https://www.kartemquin.com/films/in-the-game/"><em>In The Game</em></a>. <span></span>This warm and often heart-tugging look at four years in the life of a girls' soccer team at Chicago's inner city Kelly High School in the Brighton Park neighborhood is an intimate study in sisterhood and hope in the face of adversity. Award-winning director Maria Finitzo (<em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/item/show/8319508081_5_girls">5 Girls</a>, Terra Incognita</em>) underlines the solid sense of family that young players discover in the team setting, as rocky home lives, poverty, and the political forces that dictate slashes to the school's budget conspire to limit their prospects for a bright future.  Running time: 78 minutes. The screening will be followed by a discussion.</p><span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago </a>season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Taxidermy 101</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Does taxidermy scare you, or make you curious? Have you ever wondered why we react to death the way we do, or if there are other appropriate reactions to death? Are you interested to see some unique pieces of taxidermy, including a piece that was once in the basement of a funeral parlor in Madison, Wisconsin, in a collection called "The Dead Friends of Sam San Fillipo?"</p><p>If you are mildly curious about any of these things, this is the program for you. Amateur taxidermy collector and children's librarian Sharon Gissy will show off some of the gems of her taxidermy collection, and talk about how she acquired specific pieces, how taxidermy can teach about nature and death, and how we can learn lessons about science and history from taxidermy.</p><p>Taxidermy 101 is recommended for children ages 10 &amp; up, and curious adults. Parents and caregivers, you are the best judge of whether your children can attend this program and handle its content. Taxidermy can be respectfully handled during the program.</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/560eb8f20a8ecbcc32073de6</link>

      <item>
        <title>The Old Town School of Folk Music Presents Harmonica Hinds and Paul Kaye with Chicago Blues from 1930s to 1960s  </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/6fb1d426dc47795ac444175a2e1b60c2/PaulKaye.jpg" unselectable="on" style="width: 177px; height: 211.53px;"></p>Join Paul's duo as they present the music of Blind Blake, Big Bill and Tampa Red through to the "Chess Masters" of the 50s-60s, like Muddy Waters, Honeyboy Edwards, Little Walter and more.       <item>
        <title>Rising from the Ashes: the Rebuilding of Warsaw in the Wake of the Holocaust</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>In 1939 Hitler and the Nazi party were intent on destroying Warsaw.  By the time of the liberation from German occupation in January, 1945, 85% of the city had been destroyed.  Margaret Guzek, writer and preservationist, discusses the events leading up to the destruction of Warsaw and the subsequent post-war reconstruction which includes the recognition of Warsaw's restoration of its historic quarters as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.</p>]]></description>

        <title>Jumpstart’s Read for the Record® Story Time</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Join us for a story time in support of the 10th anniversary of <a href="http://www.jstart.org/campaigns/read-for-the-record">Jumpstart's Read for the Record</a><em>®</em>, a global campaign that generates public support for high-quality early learning and highlights the importance of building children's vocabulary and love for reading.         <title>Game Up! @ Harold Washington Library Center</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Clock out and Game Up! with CPL and <a href="http://www.dnainfo.com/chicago/20150903/lakeview/board-game-gurus-rolling-dice-with-bonus-round-game-cafe" target="_blank">Bonus Round Games</a> in an evening game extravaganza.</p><p>Grab your friends and your favorite board game and swing by the 6th floor between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. for a night of conversation and fun.       <item>
        <title>Wycinanki Workshop: The Art of Polish Paper Cutouts</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Polish cutouts wycinanki (pronounced "vee-chee-non-kee" ) are the result of cutting, clipping, punching, tearing and carving of paper into sometimes abstract and at other times recognizable forms. Among the many types of wycinanki are gwiazdy (stars), kodry (composite designs) and nalepianki (multiple layers). Grace Bazylewski has been a teacher and practitioner of this intricate folk art form for over 35 years. Participants will create their own decorative, colorful wycinanki designs to take home!</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/560bf887b13a22c97b06861b</link>

      <item>
        <title>20 Moments: Chicago in the 20th Century </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px; float: right;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/1bc8a8d1610a1d53427e965ff7480e5c/MaxGrinnell-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"></p>What is Chicago? What will Chicago be in the future? What has Chicago been in the recent past? These are all complex questions that fascinate Chicagoans, whether they have been here five months or fifty years. Drawing on historic photographs and visual materials from the Chicago Public Library, the Chicago History Museum, and other institutions, urbanologist <a href="http://theurbanologist.com/">Max Grinnell</a> will invite patrons into a discussion of these themes via a presentation with time for conversation and discussion afterwards.<span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f07d1016760c7d5202c669</link>

        <description><![CDATA[<p><b>Chicago</b><b> Financial Planning Day 2015</b></p><p><b>Saturday, October 24, 2015</b></p><p><b>Time: 9:45 a.m. – 3 p.m.</b></p><p>Chicago Financial Planning Day presents a variety of programs with a focus on personal finances during tough economic times.Certified Financial Planner professionals will be available for one-on-one 15 min. sessions, to offer advice on personal finances.Workshop programs will be offered throughout the day, addressing a variety of topics.Staff will be available to direct you.</p><p><b><u data-redactor-tag="u">Schedule of Events</u></b></p><p><b><u data-redactor-tag="u">Registration is Required</u></b></p><p><b>9:45 a.m.: Registrations Begins</b></p><p><b>Registration Location: Grand Lobby, First Floor</b></p><p><b><i data-redactor-tag="i">All participants must first register at this location.</i></b></p><p><b><u data-redactor-tag="u">Judy McNiff: How to Tame the Money Monster: Keynote Address.</u></b></p><p><b><u data-redactor-tag="u">10:15 a.m.—11 a.m., </u></b><u><strong data-redactor-tag="strong">Cindy Pritzker Auditorium, lower level.</strong></u></p><p><b><u data-redactor-tag="u">  <em>For more information on Ms. McNiff's keynote address, <a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/search/q=judy/event/561d158857e4ffa404090004">CLICK HERE</a>. </em></u></b></p><p><b><u data-redactor-tag="u">Free Financial Consultations</u></b></p><p><b>11:00 a.m.—3 p.m.</b></p><p>Multipurpose Room, Lower Level</p><p>Financial planners from the Financial Planning Association of Illinois will provide free, one-on-one, 15 minute sessions.<i>Participants will be served in the order of their arrival</i>.</p><p><b><u data-redactor-tag="u">Financial Planning Workshops</u></b></p><p>Workshops take place in the Lower Level and are available on a <i>first come, first served</i> basis.</p><p><b>11:15 a.m.—12:15 p.m.</b></p><p>Forging Your Financial Future: Reception Hall</p><p>Understanding Social Security &amp;       <item>
        <title>Native Chicago</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Please join us in a fun interactive program to learn science and to build a relationship with the land of Chicago through stories, observations and critical thinking. We will walk through the Lincoln Square neighborhood and learn and discuss historical uses of native plants that still live all around us, including medicinal and edible uses. Participants will leave with a better understanding of the land around them and be able to correctly identify and utilize common plants in Chicago. This program is funded by the Native American Heritage Committee of Chicago Public Library.</p><p>Recommended for children ages 6 &amp; up. Registration and field trip permission form are required and must be returned no later than Saturday, October 17th.</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Sculpture Among Us: Inspiring Communities Through Art with Chicago Sculpture International </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="line-height: 1.6em;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/ce18a587839ce3117912567395c3fc99/ChicagoSculptureInternational.jpg" unselectable="on"></p><p>Chicago area artists with <a href="http://www.chicagosculpture.org/">Chicago Sculpture International</a> present their work, followed by moderated discussions about what sculpture and art gives to communities and how they work with communities to create public art.  This program features the following artists - <br></p><p><b><img style="line-height: 1.6em;" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/dadefe82c07eda5c44af7cf147ba497c/Margot McMahon-Flock.jpg" unselectable="on"></b></p><p><b>Margot McMahon:</b> Margot will present the concepts of creating a Supportive Art Community with a PowerPoint presentation, brochures, historical references based on what exists now in Oak Park. OPAAC initiated the mini-mural program, outdoor sculpture exhibits, poetry on the sidewalk, with a lease to own program. It grew into Public Art Advisory Commission that collected sculptures and murals and has an annual sculpture walk. This began with sharing programs with Vi Daley and the LPCAI which has grown into CSE. The concept has been to make contemporary art the new reason to revisit Oak Park and Lincoln Park, now Lakeview and beyond after seeing Hemingway's museum and Frank Lloyd Wright Home and studio and Chicago's museums.</p><p><b><img style="line-height: 1.6em;" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/5e2925f95c93b91ff693f6e89c069199/Mike Helbing- Medusa.jpg" unselectable="on"></b></p><p><b>Mike Helbing:</b> Mike's presentation will touch upon his ideas and art and how his work engages the public mind. He will speak about the essence of a thought and how he incorporates his ideas into an artwork that speaks to people - From war and back - and his involvement in the National Veterans Art Museum.</p><p><b><img style="line-height: 1.6em;" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/b89352fc535b49c5b57468a37206aa80/Laurie Le Breton- Sentinels.jpg" unselectable="on"></b></p><p><b>Laurie Le Breton: </b>Laurie Le Breton will show images of paper making and demonstrate using wet paper for sculpture. She will also show examples of her work. Le Breton has shown her work at two Chicago libraries, the Richard J. Daley Library and the West Lawn Branch Library.<br></p><p><b><span data-redactor-tag="span"></span></b>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme "Chicago: The City That Gives."</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f07d9216760c7d5202c66d</link>
        <guid>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f07d9216760c7d5202c66d</guid>                <bc:start_date>2015-10-24T18:00:00Z</bc:start_date>

        <title>Make a Jack O’Lantern Face Sticker Set with the Electronic Cutter</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p> Learn the basics of Inkscape software as you create a design and cut out a Jack O'Lantern sticker set using the electronic cutter.       <item>
        <title>Authors Mona Golabek and Lee Cohen discuss &quot;The Children of Willesden Lane&quot;</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Chicago Public Library hosts a discussion focused on the acclaimed book titled <a id="ember2767" href="/item/show/8741233081" data-add-title-link="8741233081"><em>The Children of Willesden Lane</em></a><i> </i> with authors Mona Golabek and Lee Cohen. Golabek and Cohen discuss the ways in which a story of courage and survival set during WWII is having a profound influence and effect on the lives of 21st Century youth. The program also incorporates a video introducing the forthcoming documentary on Mona Golabek and her journey to bring her mother's story to today's young people. Golabek, who is also an acclaimed pianist, provides a brief musical performance.</p><p>This program offers a <em>sneak peek </em>of Golabek's one-woman theatrical benefit performance of <em>The Children of Willesden Lane</em>, to be presented at the Harris Theater on October 29. For information, <a href="http://harristheaterchicago.org/events/2015-2016-season/urban-gateways"><strong>click HERE</strong></a>.</p><p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/3ba5baac1af047beccb8f7d6ed1cb60c/WillesdenLane_300x230.jpg"></p><p>Seating in the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium is first come, first served (385 max.).         <description><![CDATA[<p>      We will discuss  <a id="ember6245" href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/item/show/8855434081" data-add-title-link="8855434081"><u>The Just City</u></a> by Jo Walton. Created as an experiment by the time-traveling goddess Pallas Athene, <em>The Just City </em>is a planned community based on Plato's Republic, populated by over 10,000 children and 100 adult teachers from all eras of history, along with some handy robots from the far human future--all set down together on a Mediterranean island in the distant past.         <title>Giving and Donating: Being Smart with Your Support </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/502ced6e037c8f538b3c4338f055c39d/KarenChan-resized.jpg"></p>When you make a donation, are you getting the most bang for your buck? Doing it the smart way could mean tax breaks for you and greater results for your community.         <description><![CDATA[<p> Wishing you could design a home like the architects in <em>The Third Coast</em>? This program is presented as part of One Book, One Chicago's 2015-2016 season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives" and is part of the Chicago Architecture Biennial partnership. <span></span></p><p><span></span>Registered attendees must be present within five minutes of the program's stated start time or risk forfeiting their seat.       <item>
        <title>20 Moments: Chicago in the 20th Century </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px; float: right;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/1bc8a8d1610a1d53427e965ff7480e5c/MaxGrinnell-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"></p>What is Chicago? What will Chicago be in the future? What has Chicago been in the recent past? These are all complex questions that fascinate Chicagoans, whether they have been here five months or fifty years. Drawing on historic photographs and visual materials from the Chicago Public Library, the Chicago History Museum, and other institutions, urbanologist <a href="http://theurbanologist.com/">Max Grinnell</a> will invite patrons into a discussion of these themes via a presentation with time for conversation and discussion afterwards.<span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016<a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/"> One Book, One Chicago </a>season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>A Conversation with Teddy Cruz </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><a href="http://estudioteddycruz.com/"><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/8e48f65a57b9ed54c92342af6f267c6d/TeddyCruz-resized.jpg" unselectable="on"><span></span></a></p><p><a href="http://estudioteddycruz.com/">Teddy Cruz </a>is a Rome Prize-winning architect who uses the Tijuana-San Diego border as a laboratory to re-think global dynamics, including the issues of hospitality inherent in immigration issues and the expanded gap between wealth and poverty. Architectural historian Dianne Harris will interview Teddy Cruz about the societal implication of his architectural work.<span></span><br></p><p>Seating in the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium is first come, first served, limit of 385. </p><p>This program is presented as part of <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org">One Book, One Chicago</a>'s 2015-2016 season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p><p>This program is presented in partnership with the <a href="https://www.ilhumanities.org/">Illinois Humanities Council</a> and <a href="http://chicagoarchitecturebiennial.org/">Chicago Architecture Biennial. </a></p><p><img style="width: 141px; height: 141px;" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/3d752f112f88ff11c88101b6d79825fe/ChicagoArchitectureBiennial.jpg" unselectable="on"></p><p><img style="width: 211px; height: 94.95px;" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/3f1d1880cd6feef68bedb3cc01484a4b/ILHumanities-resized.jpg" unselectable="on"></p><br>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Adult Book Discussion</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Please join our discussion of <a id="ember4020" data-add-title-link="8678627081" href="/item/show/8678627081">The Third Coast</a> by Thomas Dyja, a critically acclaimed history of Chicago at mid-century, featuring many of the incredible personalities that shaped American culture. Before air travel overtook trains, nearly every coast-to-coast journey included a stop in Chicago, and this flow of people and commodities made it the crucible for American culture and innovation.</p>]]></description>

        <title>Fairy Tale Story Dance</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Tiffany Lawson Dance will present music and movement fairy tale program for small children with big imaginations.       <item>
        <title>Start Writing Fiction</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/f94fa661fc65a2f6ec15bb122266dc29/p2pu-logo.jpg" alt="" style="float: right; margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px;"></p><p>Learn how to get started with your own fiction writing, focusing first on the central skill of creating characters.<span></span><span></span><span></span></p><p>In <a href="http://www.knightfoundation.org/grants/201550344/" target="_blank">partnership</a> with <a href="https://p2pu.org/en/" target="_blank">Peer 2 Peer University</a>, we're hosting study groups for learners who want to complete online courses together, in-person at the library.       <item>
        <title>The Third Coast: A One Book One Chicago Discussion</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Chicago, once America's "primary meeting place, market, workshop and lab" is the subject of Thomas Dyja's <a id="ember17496" href="/item/show/8896710081" data-add-title-link="8896710081">The Third Coast</a>. This cultural history of Chicago at mid-century, with its incredible mix of architects, politicians, musicians, writers, entrepreneurs and actors who helped shape modern America is this year's <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> selection.</p><p>This discussion is part of our Bezazian @the Bar series of Chicago-themed book discussions which take place on the last Wednesday of every month at Lady Gregory's Irish Pub at 5260 N. Clark in Andersonville.</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/560ed9cd0a8ecbcc320743d4</link>
        <guid>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/560ed9cd0a8ecbcc320743d4</guid>                <bc:start_date>2015-10-29T00:00:00Z</bc:start_date>

        <bc:is_featured>false</bc:is_featured>
        <bc:is_featured_at_location>false</bc:is_featured_at_location>
        <category domain="Program">One Book, One Chicago</category><category domain="Type">Book Clubs</category><category domain="Audience">Adults</category><category domain="Language">English</category>
          <bc:location>

      <item>
        <title>Cindy Pritzker Lecture on Urban Life and Issues: A Conversation with Mayor Rahm Emanuel</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/6d3e627d7ba10ff391dbefd55c25d261/MayorEmanuelPhoto.jpg" alt="" style="line-height: 1.6em; margin: auto; display: block;">The 2015 Cindy Pritzker Lecture on Urban Life and Issues presents a conversation with Mayor Rahm Emanuel. Rahm Emanuel has served as the 55th mayor of the City of Chicago since 2011. During that time he has been a tireless advocate for the residents of Chicago, working to create jobs and bring educational, economic, and cultural opportunities to neighborhoods in all parts of the city. Under Mayor Emanuel's leadership, Chicago has played an increasing role in driving the global conversation about confronting urban challenges. Chicago has been recognized by several studies for its economic competitiveness and has received multiple awards for the quality of its museums, parks, and public libraries.<br></p><p>Prior to becoming Mayor, Emanuel served as the White House Chief of Staff to President Barack Obama and served three terms in the U.S. House of Representatives representing Chicago's 5th District. He previously served as a key member of the Clinton administration from 1993 to 1998, rising to serve as Senior Advisor to the President for Policy and Strategy.</p><p>Mayor Emanuel appears in conversation with Scott Turow, the acclaimed, bestselling Chicago author of novels such as One L, Ordinary Heroes and many others.<span></span><br></p><p><b><strong data-redactor-tag="strong"></strong></b>The Cindy Pritzker Lecture on Urban Life and Issues is presented by the Board of Directors of the Chicago Public Library in honor of Cindy Pritzker, its former president and founder of the Chicago Public Library Foundation.</p><p><b>REGISTRATION and SEATING:</b> Registration is kindly requested. Please register at Eventbrite by <a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/cindy-pritzker-lecture-on-urban-life-and-issues-a-conversation-with-mayor-rahm-emanuel-tickets-18885497030">CLICKING HERE</a>. If all venue spaces fill to capacity, registration does not guarantee seating. Once the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium reaches capacity, guests will be seated in an overflow space and view the event by live simulcast. Available seating will be provided <i>first come, first served</i>, beginning at 5 p.m. on Oct. 29.</p><p><em></em><br></p>]]></description>

        <title>Film Screening: Art and Craft</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Join us for the screening of the documentary film,<strong><em> Art and Craft, </em></strong>directed by <strong>Sam Cullman, Jennifer Grausman, and Mark Becker. </strong>Mark Landis is one of the most prolific art forgers of the modern era — and he isn't in it for the money. In the last 30 years he's copied hundreds of pieces, from 15th-century icons to works by Picasso and even Dr. Seuss, then donated them to museums across the country. When a tenacious registrar discovers the ruse, Landis must confront his legacy and a chorus of duped professionals intent on stopping him. This event is a collaboration with POV, PBS' award-winning nonfiction film series. <span></span></p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Make a Bookmark with the Laser Cutter</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Learn the basics of Inkscape software as you create a design and cut out a bookmark using the laser cutter.</p><p> Registered attendees must be present within five minutes of the program's stated start time or risk forfeiting their seat. Walk-ins are welcome as space allows. Classes and workshops at the Maker Lab are for ages 14 and up. Children 10-14 may attend with an adult, but no more than two children per adult may register, and the adult must take responsibility for the children at all times. All attendees must have basic computer and mouse skills. If you have a group of more than five people, please contact us for a private class by emailing <a href="mailto:makerspace@chipublib.org">makerspace@chipublib.org</a>.<span></span><br></p>]]></description>

Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn, authors of <a id="ember9921" href="/item/show/8413335081" data-add-title-link="8413335081">Half the Sky</a> <span></span>and <a id="ember9922" href="/item/show/8812087081" data-add-title-link="8812087081">A Path Appears</a>, explore how altruism affects us, what are the markers for success, and how to avoid the pitfalls.       <item>
        <title>A Conversation with Thomas Dyja, author of The Third Coast</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/c8b50c9bc6617f727cec7956269baec0/ThomasDyjaPhotoCreditBill Guerriero-resized.jpg" unselectable="on"></p>Award-winning author and third generation Chicagoan Thomas Dyja appears in the headline event of this OBOC season to discuss <em>The Third Coast</em>. Dyja will also address how this season's theme, Chicago: The City That Gives, can be found in the growth and shaping of the city of Chicago both in the past and present day.<span></span><p><br></p><p>Thomas Dyja was born and raised on the Northwest Side, a third generation Chicagoan. One of his grandfathers was a waiter at the Edgewater Beach Hotel; the other made pipes at Chicago Faucet. A graduate of Columbia University, he stayed in New York after college to go into publishing. After working as a bookseller and some time on the agency side at ICM, he went to Bantam Books, where he dealt with popular culture, from the original Rotisserie League series to Richard Saul Wurman, creator of the TED conference. From there, he became a partner in the book packaging company Balliett &amp; Fitzgerald, creating books for clients such as <em>ESPN</em>, <i>People</i> magazine, <i>USATODAY</i>, and <em>A&amp;E</em> Television and editing four anthologies. From packaging he went on to write three novels (<i><a id="ember11808" href="/item/show/1394197081" data-add-title-link="1394197081">Play for A Kingdom</a><span></span></i>, <i><a id="ember11809" href="/item/show/1795760081" data-add-title-link="1795760081">Meet John Trow</a><span></span></i>, and <i><a id="ember11810" href="/item/show/1989853081" data-add-title-link="1989853081">The Moon in Our Hands</a><span></span></i>), a biography of civil rights pioneer <a id="ember11811" href="/item/show/8351098081" data-add-title-link="8351098081">Walter White</a><span></span>, and to co-write a book on education with former New York schools chancellor Dr. Rudy Crew titled <i><a id="ember11812" href="/item/show/2201407081" data-add-title-link="2201407081">Only Connect</a><span></span></i>. <a id="ember4775" href="/item/show/8678627081" data-add-title-link="8678627081">The Third Coast</a> won the Heartland Prize for Non-fiction in 2013 and was one of the New York Times's Notable Books of the Year. Dyja lives in Manhattan with his wife, literary agent Suzanne Gluck. They have a son in college and a daughter in high school.<span></span><br></p><p>Seating in the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium is first come, first served, limit of 385. Books will be available for sale, and the author will sign books at the conclusion of the program.</p><p>This program is presented as part of <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org">One Book, One Chicago</a>'s 2015-2016 season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f081a816760c7d5202c71a</link>
        <guid>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f081a816760c7d5202c71a</guid>                <bc:start_date>2015-11-05T00:00:00Z</bc:start_date>
        <bc:end_date>2015-11-05T02:00:00Z</bc:end_date>
        <bc:is_cancelled>false</bc:is_cancelled>

        <title>Baby Can Boogie</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Baby Can Boogie is a music and movement program best for ages 0-4 years.Singing slows down language so children can hear the different sounds that make up words. Music provides opportunities for children to develop basic math skills, like sequencing, patterning, matching and counting. In this 45 minute program, young children and their parents will sing, clap and dance their way to strong early literacy and math skills. </p><p>Baby Can Boogie 是音乐和运动项目最适合年龄0-4岁孩子。歌唱减慢的语言，所以孩子们可以听到不同的发音，使单词。音乐提供了机会，给儿童发展基本的数学技能，如排序，图形，匹配和计数。在45分钟的节目，年幼的孩子和他们的父母会唱歌，拍手跳舞的方式加 强早期识字和数学技能。</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: The Exiles</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p> Film screening of <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">The Exiles </em></strong>by <strong>Kent Mackenzie</strong>. For 12 hours, one Friday night, from late afternoon until dawn, we follow a handful of urban Native Americans living in the Bunker Hill district of Los Angeles. Yvonne is pregnant, commenting on her life and dreams as she shops, cooks dinner, and watches her husband Homer leave with his friends. Homer and his pals go bar hopping, play some poker, and end up, bottles in hand, with other Native Americans on a hilltop. During the night, the men pick up women, there are fights, there's camaraderie, and Homer reflects on life in the city versus life on the reservation. This film originally premiered at the Venice Film Festival in 1961; the restored version premiered July 11, 2008, in New York. (72 min.)</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/562140d716760c7d5209e291</link>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: Up Heartbreak Hill</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Film screening of <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">Up Heartbreak Hill </em></strong>by <strong>Erica Scharf.</strong> Thomas and Tamara are track stars at their rural New Mexico high school. Like many teenagers, they are torn between the lure of brighter futures elsewhere and the ties that bind them to home. For these teens, however, home is an impoverished town on the Navajo reservation, and leaving means separating from family, tradition and the land that has been theirs for generations. <em>Up Heartbreak Hill </em>is a moving look at a new generation of Americans struggling to be both Native and modern. A co-production of Long Distance Films, Native American Public Telecommunications, ITVS, POV's Diverse Voices Project and New Mexico PBS, with funding provided by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. A co-presentation with Native American Public Telecommunications. Premiere date: July 26, 2012. (60 min.)</p>]]></description>

        <title>Bouncing Babies</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>A story time filled with nursery rhymes, songs and simple books, as well as lots of bouncing. The program lasts about 20-30 minutes with free time afterwards to make new friends and engage in active play with board books and age-appropriate toys.</p><p><strong>Age range:</strong> 3-18 months with a participating adult caregiver.       <item>
        <title>Chicago’s Public Art: Out of the Past, Into the Future </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/1bc8a8d1610a1d53427e965ff7480e5c/MaxGrinnell-sized.jpg" alt="" style="float: right; margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px;"></p>Chicago's well-known and robust public art culture remains the envy of other major cities around the world. In this presentation, urbanologist <a href="http://theurbanologist.com/">Max Grinnell</a> will offer up some of his thoughts on the transformative qualities of Chicago's various public art initiatives, including the Percent for Art Program, the Chicago Public Art Group, and other lesser-known programs. Based on his extensive exploration of the city from O'Hare's Terminal 5 to Pullman, this program will be an engaging look into how Chicago's public art programs, formal and informal, continue to engage the interest of locals and visitors.<span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Arthur Sheridan: The Harold A. Bezazian Lecture</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Born in Uptown, graduated from Senn High School, Arthur Sheridan went on to be part of the 20th Armored Division during WWII and, among other feats, participated in the liberation of the Dachau concentration camp. After the war, Sheridan returned to Chicago, manufactured, produced and distributed music records, opened several jazz clubs and then became a commercial real estate developer and steel company owner. This first annual Harold A. Bezazian lecture honors an Uptowner who has had an extraordinary life and is sponsored by the <a href="mailto:friendsofbezazian@gmail.com">Friends of Bezazian</a>.</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Oh Freedom, Songs of the Civil Rights Movement with Chris Vallillo </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px; float: left;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/cbe9fc248618999e74b2811c2aa63b93/ChrisV-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"><br></p><p><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br></p><p><br>Learn about how music has contributed to community. The Civil Rights Movement has been described as one of the greatest singing movements that this country has experienced. From "We Shall Overcome" to "This Little Light of Mine", music played a vital role in that historic struggle both as an inspirational rallying point and as a way to spread the message of equality and justice. </p><p>In a show created to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the civil rights movement, award winning Illinois folksinger <a href="http://ginridge.com/">Chris Vallillo</a> performs pivotal songs from the music that inspired and sustained this landmark movement. Intermixed with the music, Vallillo presents firsthand accounts of the historic struggle and discusses the impact of music to our nation's most important social cause.<span></span><br></p><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."<br></p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Chicago’s Public Art: Out of the Past, Into the Future </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/1bc8a8d1610a1d53427e965ff7480e5c/MaxGrinnell-sized.jpg" alt="" style="float: right; margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px;"></p>Chicago's well-known and robust public art culture remains the envy of other major cities around the world. In this presentation, urbanologist <a href="http://theurbanologist.com/">Max Grinnell</a> will offer up some of his thoughts on the transformative qualities of Chicago's various public art initiatives, including the Percent for Art Program, the Chicago Public Art Group, and other lesser-known programs. Based on his extensive exploration of the city from O'Hare's Terminal 5 to Pullman, this program will be an engaging look into how Chicago's public art programs, formal and informal, continue to engage the interest of locals and visitors.<span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."</p>]]></description>

        <title>The Third Coast: A One Book One Chicago Discussion</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Chicago, once America's "primary meeting place, market, workshop and lab" is the subject of Thomas Dyja's <a id="ember10027" href="/item/show/8896710081" data-add-title-link="8896710081">The Third Coast</a>. This cultural history of Chicago at mid-century, with its incredible mix of architects, politicians, musicians, writers, entrepreneurs and actors who helped shape modern America is this year's <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book One Chicago</a> selection.</p><p><br></p>]]></description>

        <title>Ehdrigohr: Native American Role Playing Game</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Legendary local game designer <a href="http://www.cdm.depaul.edu/about/Pages/People/FacultyInfo.aspx?fid=465">Allen Turner</a> will walk you through his Native American themed role playing game <a href="http://council-of-fools.com/blog/">Ehdrigohr</a>.       <item>
        <title>Oh Freedom, Songs of the Civil Rights Movement with Chris Vallillo </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px; float: left;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/cbe9fc248618999e74b2811c2aa63b93/ChrisV-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><span></span>Learn about how music has contributed to community. The Civil Rights Movement has been described as one of the greatest singing movements that this country has experienced. From "We Shall Overcome" to "This Little Light of Mine", music played a vital role in that historic struggle both as an inspirational rallying point and as a way to spread the message of equality and justice. </p><p>In a show created to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the civil rights movement, award winning Illinois folksinger <a href="http://ginridge.com/">Chris Vallillo</a> performs pivotal songs from the music that inspired and sustained this landmark movement. Intermixed with the music, Vallillo presents firsthand accounts of the historic struggle and discusses the impact of music to our nation's most important social cause.<span></span><br></p><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."<br></p>]]></description>

        <title>The Absolutely True Diary of A Part-Time Indian</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p> In <a id="ember13923" href="/item/show/2219210081" data-add-title-link="2219210081">The Absolutely True Diary of A Part-time Indian</a>, Arnold Spirit "Junior", a talented cartoonist and writer growing up on the Spokane Indian Reservation, makes a fateful decision to attend an all-white farm town high school where the only other Indian is the school mascot. He faces trouble fitting in with his white peers while he is also the target of bullies and ridicule back on the rez, adding up to a nuanced view of culture, identity, and community. Little, Brown Books For Young Readers, 2009. (Ages 12 &amp; Up)</p>]]></description>

        <title>Thanksgiving: The Indigenous Perspective</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>This interactive multimedia presentation examines the history of <strong>Thanksgiving</strong> through the<strong> Indigenous Perspective</strong>.       <item>
        <title>Author Lisa Randall discusses &quot;Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs: The Astounding Interconnectedness of the Universe&quot;</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Acclaimed author and physicist <strong>Lisa Randall </strong>makes a highly-anticipated return appearance to discuss her new book titled <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs: The Astounding Interconnectedness of the Universe</em></strong>. Co-sponsored by <a href="http://www.illinoisscience.org/"><strong>ISC/Illinois Science Council</strong></a>.</p><p> In <i>Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs</i>, Randall tells a breathtaking story that weaves together the cosmos' history and our own, illuminating the deep relationships that are critical to our world--and the astonishing beauty inherent in the most familiar things. "Dark matter" and "dinosaurs" might sound like an unusual pairing. This book explores a speculative scenario in which a disk of dark matter-- the elusive stuff in the universe that interacts through gravity like ordinary matter, but that doesn't emit or absorb light –dislodged a comet from the Oort cloud that was ultimately responsible for the dinosaurs' extinction. Working through the background and consequences that led to this proposal, Randall teaches us an enormous amount—both established and speculative--about dark matter, our Universe, our galaxy, asteroids, and comets--and the process by which scientists explore new concepts. Many people are fascinated by the idea of a multiverse—other universes not within our reach. But at least as fascinating are the many hidden worlds—both biological and physical —that we do have a chance to explore and understand. <i>Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs</i> teaches us about known structure in the Universe and the Solar System, speculates further about possible missing elements, and illustrates the importance of preserving the elements on Earth--so long in the making--that are vital to our existence.</p><p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/7d1919ce8eb40edb2c86c5fcddd761cb/Randall, Lisa PHOTO Nov 2015.jpg" unselectable="on"> Photo credit: Rose Lincoln/Harvard Staff Photographer</p><p>  <b>Lisa Randall </b> studies theoretical particle physics and cosmology at Harvard University where she is Frank B. Baird, Jr., Professor of Science. A member of the National Academy of Sciences, the American Philosophical Society, and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, Randall is the recipient of many awards and honorary degrees. Professor Randall was included in <em>Time </em>magazine's<em> </em>"100 Most Influential People" of 2007, was among <em>Esquire m</em>agazine's<em> </em>"75 Most Influential People of the 21st Century." Professor Randall's two books, <em>Warped Passages </em>(2005) and <em>Knocking on Heaven's Door </em>(2011) were <em>New York Times </em>100 Most Influential Books. Her ebook, <em>Higgs Discovery: The Power of Empty Space</em>, was published in 2012. </p><p>Seating in the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium is first come, first served (385 max.). Books are available for purchase and the author will autograph books at the conclusion of the program.</p><p><img style="width: 280px; height: 78.96px;" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/ae2fefb06417e8aeed22d05af5f5ebb7/ISC Illinois Science Council LOGO 2015.jpg" unselectable="on"><br></p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55d4a5aa88879a070d0291ed</link>
        <guid>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55d4a5aa88879a070d0291ed</guid>                <bc:start_date>2015-11-11T00:00:00Z</bc:start_date>
        <bc:end_date>2015-11-11T01:30:00Z</bc:end_date>
        <bc:is_cancelled>false</bc:is_cancelled>
        <bc:is_featured>true</bc:is_featured>
        <bc:is_featured_at_location>false</bc:is_featured_at_location>
        <category domain="Type">Author Events</category><category domain="Audience">Adults</category><category domain="Language">English</category>
          <bc:location>
            <bc:name>Harold Washington Library Center</bc:name>
            <bc:latitude>41.876755</bc:latitude><bc:longitude>-87.627872</bc:longitude><bc:number>400</bc:number><bc:street>S.       <item>
        <title>Oh Freedom, Songs of the Civil Rights Movement with Chris Vallillo </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px; float: left;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/cbe9fc248618999e74b2811c2aa63b93/ChrisV-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><span></span>Learn about how music has contributed to community. The Civil Rights Movement has been described as one of the greatest singing movements that this country has experienced. From "We Shall Overcome" to "This Little Light of Mine", music played a vital role in that historic struggle both as an inspirational rallying point and as a way to spread the message of equality and justice. </p><p>In a show created to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the civil rights movement, award winning Illinois folksinger <a href="http://ginridge.com/">Chris Vallillo</a> performs pivotal songs from the music that inspired and sustained this landmark movement. Intermixed with the music, Vallillo presents firsthand accounts of the historic struggle and discusses the impact of music to our nation's most important social cause.<span></span><br></p><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."<br></p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f07a2c16760c7d5202c44d</link>

      <item>
        <title>Newspaper Genealogical Resources</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Learn to use CPL's historical Chicago newspapers, city directories, phone books and equipment to find obituaries, news items, and addresses for your Chicago ancestors.</p><p>Rare Chicago newspapers from as far back as the 1850s may contain information about your Chicago ancestors you can't find anywhere else!</p><p>Participants will learn to search the <i>Chicago Tribune</i>, <i>Chicago Defender</i>, <i>Chicago Sun-Times</i>, and <em>Chicago Examiner </em>databases for obituaries and other news items. There will also be a demonstration of how to use microfilm to access many other Chicago newspapers that aren't available online.</p><p> Seating is limited. First come, first served.<br></p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>20 Moments: Chicago in the 20th Century </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px; float: right;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/1bc8a8d1610a1d53427e965ff7480e5c/MaxGrinnell-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"></p>What is Chicago? What will Chicago be in the future? What has Chicago been in the recent past? These are all complex questions that fascinate Chicagoans, whether they have been here five months or fifty years. Drawing on historic photographs and visual materials from the Chicago Public Library, the Chicago History Museum, and other institutions, urbanologist <a href="http://theurbanologist.com/">Max Grinnell</a> will invite patrons into a discussion of these themes via a presentation with time for conversation and discussion afterwards.<span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 One Book, One Chicago season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Author John Irving Discusses &quot;Avenue of Mysteries&quot;</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p> <img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/3431b5f76627d4c2de525ee3d813c75e/Irving, John PHOTO Nov 2015.jpg" unselectable="on"></p><p><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?q=%22Irving%2C+John%22&amp;search_category=author&amp;t=author">John Irving</a> makes a long-awaited appearance at Chicago Public Library!<strong>  </strong>In his new book, <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">Avenue of Mysteries</em></strong>, Irving<strong> </strong>returns to the themes that established him as one of our most admired and beloved authors in this absorbing novel of fate and memory.</p><p>As we grow older—most of all, in what we remember and what we dream—we live in the past. Sometimes, we live more vividly in the past than in the present.</p><p>As an older man, Juan Diego will take a trip to the Philippines, but what travels with him are his dreams and memories; he is most alive in his childhood and early adolescence in Mexico. "An aura of fate had marked him," Irving writes, of Juan Diego. "The chain of events, the links in our lives—what leads us where we're going, the courses we follow to our ends, what we don't see coming, and what we do—all this can be mysterious, or simply unseen, or even obvious."</p><p><em>Avenue of Mysteries </em>is the story of what happens to Juan Diego in the Philippines, where what happened to him in the past—in Mexico—collides with his future.</p><p>John Irving was born in Exeter, New Hampshire, in 1942. His first novel, <em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?custom_query=(contributor%3A(John%20Irving)%20AND%20title%3A(Setting%20Free%20the%20Bears)%20)&amp;suppress=true&amp;custom_edit=false">Setting Free the Bears</a></em>, was published in 1968, when he was 26. He competed as a wrestler for 20 years, and coached wrestling until he was 47. Irving has been nominated for a National Book Award three times—winning once, in 1980, for his novel <em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?custom_query=(contributor%3A(John%20Irving)%20AND%20title%3A(The%20World%20According%20to%20Garp)%20)&amp;suppress=true&amp;custom_edit=false">The World According to Garp</a></em>. He received an O. Henry Award in 1981 for his short story "Interior Space." In 2000, Irving won the Oscar for Best Adapted Screenplay for <em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?custom_query=(contributor%3A(John%20Irving)%20AND%20title%3A(The%20Cider%20House%20Rule)%20)&amp;suppress=true&amp;custom_edit=false">The Cider House Rules</a></em>. In 2013, he won a Lambda Literary Award for his novel <em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?custom_query=(contributor%3A(John%20Irving)%20AND%20title%3A(In%20One%20Person)%20)&amp;suppress=true&amp;custom_edit=false">In One Person</a></em>. An international writer—his novels have been translated into more than 35 languages—Irving lives in Toronto. His all-time bestselling novel, in every language, is <em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?custom_query=(contributor%3A(John%20Irving)%20AND%20title%3A(A%20Prayer%20for%20Owen%20Meany)%20)&amp;suppress=true&amp;custom_edit=false">A Prayer for Owen Meany</a></em>. <em>Avenue of Mysteries </em>is his 14th novel.</p><p><strong>IMPORTANT INFORMATION: There will not be a public book signing for this event. A limited number of books, personally autographed by Mr. Irving, will be available for purchase at the event. The purchase of an autographed book, along with seating in the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium, is available first come, first served. Once capacity is reached in the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium (385 max.), guests will be directed to an overflow space where the event will be viewed by live simulcast.  Reservations are not required.</strong></p><p>(Photo source: Everett Irving)</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55a54793783e3d472a02b81a</link>
        <guid>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55a54793783e3d472a02b81a</guid>                <bc:start_date>2015-11-12T00:00:00Z</bc:start_date>
        <bc:end_date>2015-11-12T01:30:00Z</bc:end_date>
        <bc:is_cancelled>false</bc:is_cancelled>
        <bc:is_featured>true</bc:is_featured>
        <bc:is_featured_at_location>false</bc:is_featured_at_location>
        <category domain="Type">Author Events</category><category domain="Audience">Adults</category><category domain="Language">English</category>
          <bc:location>
            <bc:name>Harold Washington Library Center</bc:name>
            <bc:latitude>41.876755</bc:latitude><bc:longitude>-87.627872</bc:longitude><bc:number>400</bc:number><bc:street>S. State Street</bc:street><bc:city>Chicago</bc:city><bc:zip>60605</bc:zip><bc:state>IL</bc:state><bc:country>US</bc:country><bc:location_details><![CDATA[Cindy Pritzker Auditorium, Lower Level]]></bc:location_details>
          </bc:location>
        
          <bc:registration_info>
            <bc:is_required>false</bc:is_required>
                        
            <bc:is_full>false</bc:is_full>
                      </bc:registration_info>
              </item>
    
      <item>
        <title>Oh Freedom, Songs of the Civil Rights Movement with Chris Vallillo </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px; float: left;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/cbe9fc248618999e74b2811c2aa63b93/ChrisV-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><span></span>Learn about how music has contributed to community. The Civil Rights Movement has been described as one of the greatest singing movements that this country has experienced. From "We Shall Overcome" to "This Little Light of Mine", music played a vital role in that historic struggle both as an inspirational rallying point and as a way to spread the message of equality and justice. </p><p>In a show created to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the civil rights movement, award winning Illinois folksinger <a href="http://ginridge.com/">Chris Vallillo</a> performs pivotal songs from the music that inspired and sustained this landmark movement. Intermixed with the music, Vallillo presents firsthand accounts of the historic struggle and discusses the impact of music to our nation's most important social cause.<span></span><br></p><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."<br></p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f07a4716760c7d5202c452</link>

      <item>
        <title>The Old Town School of Folk Music presents Jack Cassidy&#39;s Jazz in Chicago</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="line-height: 1.6em;" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/58cab86572cce120ab9d7edf6be13bb7/JackCassidy.jpg" unselectable="on"></p><p>Come and experience the rich history of Jazz in Chicago. Jack Cassidy (keys/trumpet) and Wes John (guitar/sax) will perform tunes made famous by artists ranging from Louis Armstrong to Benny Goodman to Von Freeman. From the roaring twenties to the Austin High Gang to Chicago's famed Jazz Festival... songs, styles, stories and anecdotes from throughout the ages will be shared and discussed.<br></p><span></span><p>This program is presented as part of <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org">One Book, One Chicago 2015-2016 season</a>.         <title>Fairy Tale Story Dance</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Tiffany Lawson Dance will present music and movement fairy tale program for small children with big imaginations.       <item>
        <title>Oh Freedom, Songs of the Civil Rights Movement with Chris Vallillo </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px; float: left;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/cbe9fc248618999e74b2811c2aa63b93/ChrisV-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><span></span>Learn about how music has contributed to community. The Civil Rights Movement has been described as one of the greatest singing movements that this country has experienced. From "We Shall Overcome" to "This Little Light of Mine", music played a vital role in that historic struggle both as an inspirational rallying point and as a way to spread the message of equality and justice. </p><p>In a show created to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the civil rights movement, award winning Illinois folksinger <a href="http://ginridge.com/">Chris Vallillo</a> performs pivotal songs from the music that inspired and sustained this landmark movement. Intermixed with the music, Vallillo presents firsthand accounts of the historic struggle and discusses the impact of music to our nation's most important social cause.<span></span><br></p><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."<br></p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>A Conversation with Barry Bergdoll</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/22bb032d3f1f18d2764b37ea264a39c4/BarryBergdollcreditRobinHolland-resized.jpg" unselectable="on"></p>Curator and scholar Barry Bergdoll discusses Chicago architecture at midcentury, in particular the politics and ideals of modernism. His talk explores the belief that architecture can impart a way of life and common values, while touching upon Chicago's place in the global exchange of modern design ideas.<span></span><span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme "Chicago: The City That Gives."       <item>
        <title>Film Screening: Sun Kissed</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Film screening of <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">Sun Kissed </em></strong>by <strong>Maya Stark </strong>and <strong>Adi Lavy</strong>. When a Navajo couple discovers their children have a disorder that makes exposure to sunlight fatal, they also learn their reservation is a hotbed for this rare genetic disease. Why? <em>Sun Kissed </em>follows Dorey and Yolanda Nez as they confront cultural taboos, tribal history and their own unconventional choices to learn the shocking truth: The consequences of the Navajos' Long Walk — their forced relocation by the U.S. military in 1864 — are far from over. A co-production of ITVS, with funding provided by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. A co-presentation with Native American Public Telecommunications. Premiere date October 18, 2012.  (60 min.)</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: In the Light of Reverence</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Film screening of <em><strong data-redactor-tag="strong">In the Light of Reverence </strong></em>by <strong>Christopher McLeod </strong>and <strong>Malinda Maynor</strong>. Devils Tower. The Four Corners. Mount Shasta. All places of extraordinary beauty — and impassioned controversy — as Native Americans and other residents struggle to co-exist with very different ideas about how the land should be used. For Native Americans, the land is sacred and akin to the world's greatest cathedrals. For others, the land should be used for industry and recreation. Narrated by Peter Coyote and Tantoo Cardinal (Metis), <em>In the Light of Reverence </em>is a beautifully rendered account of the struggles of the Lakota in the Black Hills, the Hopi in Arizona, and the Wintu in California to protect their sacred sites. An Independent Television Service (ITVS) &amp; Native American Public Telecommunications (NAPT) Co-presentation and a Television Race Initiative (TRI) Selection. Premiere Date: August 14, 2001. (75 min.)</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/5621501716760c7d5209e618</link>

        <bc:is_featured>false</bc:is_featured>
        <bc:is_featured_at_location>false</bc:is_featured_at_location>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: &quot;In The Game&quot;</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/a6cc0dae4cbfe62ec006e193d1b07d64/inthegame-fence-resized.jpg" alt="" style="margin: auto; display: block;">Join us for a screening of the new documentary film from Kartemquin Films, <a href="https://www.kartemquin.com/films/in-the-game/"><em>In The Game</em></a>. <span></span>This warm and often heart-tugging look at four years in the life of a girls' soccer team at Chicago's inner city Kelly High School in the Brighton Park neighborhood is an intimate study in sisterhood and hope in the face of adversity. Award-winning director Maria Finitzo (<em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/item/show/8319508081_5_girls">5 Girls</a>, Terra Incognita</em>) underlines the solid sense of family that young players discover in the team setting, as rocky home lives, poverty, and the political forces that dictate slashes to the school's budget conspire to limit their prospects for a bright future.  Running time: 78 minutes. The screening will be followed by a discussion.</p><span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago </a>season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: &quot;In The Game&quot;</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/a6cc0dae4cbfe62ec006e193d1b07d64/inthegame-fence-resized.jpg" alt="" style="margin: auto; display: block;">Join us for a screening of the new documentary film from Kartemquin Films, <a href="https://www.kartemquin.com/films/in-the-game/"><em>In The Game</em></a>. <span></span>This warm and often heart-tugging look at four years in the life of a girls' soccer team at Chicago's inner city Kelly High School in the Brighton Park neighborhood is an intimate study in sisterhood and hope in the face of adversity. Award-winning director Maria Finitzo (<em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/item/show/8319508081_5_girls">5 Girls</a>, Terra Incognita</em>) underlines the solid sense of family that young players discover in the team setting, as rocky home lives, poverty, and the political forces that dictate slashes to the school's budget conspire to limit their prospects for a bright future.  Running time: 78 minutes. The screening will be followed by a discussion.</p><span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago </a>season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Book Buddies--A Reading Program for Kids</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Please join us as we continue a fun reading program designed for kids in approximately kindergarten through third grade. Kids who sign up should be beginning readers. Children will be matched with a special volunteer to read or play literacy-related games for one 30-minute session per week.</p><p><strong>Kids must register in advance for a weekly time slot. To register, stop by the Children's Department for an application. We will call and match you with your buddy no later than October 16, 2015.</strong></p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>The Absolutely True Diary Of A Part-Time Indian</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>In <a id="ember15220" href="/item/show/2219210081" data-add-title-link="2219210081">The Absolutely True Diary of A Part-time Indian</a>, Arnold Spirit "Junior", a talented cartoonist and writer growing up on the Spokane Indian Reservation, makes a fateful decision to attend an all-white farm town high school where the only other Indian is the school mascot. He faces trouble fitting in with his white peers while he is also the target of bullies and ridicule back on the rez, adding up to a nuanced view of culture, identity, and community. Little, Brown Books For Young Readers, 2009. (Ages 12 &amp; Up)</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Stories &amp; Stuff</title>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: Standing Silent Nation</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p> Film screening of <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">Standing Silent Nation </em></strong>by<strong> Suree Towfighnia </strong>and <strong>Courtney Hermann</strong>. What does a family have to endure to create a future for itself? In April 2000, Alex White Plume and his Lakota family planted industrial hemp on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota after other crops had failed. They put their hopes for a sustainable economy in hemp's hardiness and a booming worldwide demand for its many products, from clothing to food. Although growing hemp, a relative of marijuana, was banned in the U.S., Alex believed that tribal sovereignty, along with hemp's non-psychoactive properties, would protect him. But when federal agents raided the White Plumes' fields, the Lakota Nation was swept into a Byzantine struggle over tribal sovereignty, economic rights and common sense. A co-presentation of Native American Public Telecommunications. Premiere date July 3, 2007. (53 min)</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/562159f516760c7d5209e82d</link>

      <item>
        <title>Thanksgiving: The Indigenous Perspective</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>  This interactive multimedia presentation examines the history of <b>Thanksgiving</b> through the<b> Indigenous Perspective</b>. Uncover tribal people's first encounters with the pilgrims, learn what actually happened, and think about how those historical events have transformed into today's "celebration" of Thanksgiving. This program is presented by <b>Lawrence Santiago</b>. Santiago is an artist, architect, and Youth Development Specialist for Chicago Public School's Title VII American Indian Education Program. He is a member of the Koasati Tribe of Louisiana and Hachamaori people of the U.S. Territory of Guam. </p>]]></description>

        <title>Author Visit with John Siordia</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Meet local author John Siordia as he reads from his novel <em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/item/show/8885737081_under_cover_of_darkness">Under Cover of Darkness</a></em>. A unique blend of action, adventure and romance, <em>Under Cover of Darkness</em> reveals the story of <em>Windwalker</em>, the code name for Drew Santos, an intelligence operative for America's Department of Defense of Mexican and Native American Heritage. Siordia has researched trends in intelligence and terrorism reaching back 30-years, to lend authenticity to his writings. He has worked in security, contract guard services and undercover loss prevention.</p><p><br></p><p>Please call the library for more information.</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>The Lone Ranger and Tonto Fistfight in Heaven</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p> Join the book discussion on <a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/item/show/8765341081_the_lone_ranger_and_tonto_fistfight_in_heaven">The Lone Ranger and Tonto Fistfight in Heaven</a> by<strong> Sherman Alexie</strong>. Widely acknowledged as one of the most important contemporary Native American voices in literature, Alexie's book of interconnected short stories depicting modern life on a Spokane reservation opened many eyes in America with its insight, humor and characters such as the tough but ailing Victor and shy, sensitive Thomas Builds-The-Fire. Native American fiction. Grove Press, 2013.</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/5621641c16760c7d5209e9cd</link>

      <item>
        <title>Beyond the Building: The Social Impact of Architecture </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Projects like Rural Studio and Mass Design Group seek not just to create buildings but also to strengthen communities through the process of consultation, design and construction. How do architects try to create connections across lines of race and socioeconomics, heal, and promote peace through their processes? Speakers Alex Henderson (Rural Studio) and Marika Shiori-Clark (Co-founder of MASS Design Group) explore this and more.<span></span><span></span></p><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme "Chicago: The City That Gives."         <title>MASTERPIECE™ Book Club </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><i>"The feat was amazing, for the book is put together so deftly that I can remember no recent book of the kind, which approaches it in merit."</i><i>                                                                       </i>The British Weekly, <i>1921</i> </p><p>This review refers to Agatha Christie's first published novel, <i>The Mysterious Affair at Styles</i>. Written in 1916 and published in the US in 1920, the novel introduced Hercule Poirot, Inspector (later, Chief Inspector) Japp, and Arthur Hastings. Poirot, a Belgian refugee of the Great War, is settling in England near the home of Emily Inglethorp, who helped him to his new life. His friend Hastings arrives as a guest at her home. When the woman is killed, Poirot uses his "little grey cells" to solve the mystery.              <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">CAN YOU?</em></strong></p><p><strong><em><a id="ember2744" href="/item/show/8882291081" data-add-title-link="8882291081">The Mysterious Affair at Styles</a></em></strong></p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: The Exiles</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>  Film screening of <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">The Exiles </em></strong>by <strong>Kent Mackenzie</strong>. For 12 hours, one Friday night, from late afternoon until dawn, we follow a handful of urban Native Americans living in the Bunker Hill district of Los Angeles. Yvonne is pregnant, commenting on her life and dreams as she shops, cooks dinner, and watches her husband Homer leave with his friends. Homer and his pals go bar hopping, play some poker, and end up, bottles in hand, with other Native Americans on a hilltop. During the night, the men pick up women, there are fights, there's camaraderie, and Homer reflects on life in the city versus life on the reservation. This film originally premiered at the Venice Film Festival in 1961; the restored version premiered July 11, 2008, in New York. (72 min.)</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/56215b1716760c7d5209e874</link>

      <item>
        <title>Thanksgiving: The Indigenous Perspective</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>  This interactive multimedia presentation examines the history of <b>Thanksgiving</b> through the<b> Indigenous Perspective</b>. Uncover tribal people's first encounters with the pilgrims, learn what actually happened, and think about how those historical events have transformed into today's "celebration" of Thanksgiving. This program is presented by <b>Lawrence Santiago</b>. Santiago is an artist, architect, and Youth Development Specialist for Chicago Public School's Title VII American Indian Education Program. He is a member of the Koasati Tribe of Louisiana and Hachamaori people of the U.S. Territory of Guam. </p>]]></description>

        <title>Harsh Readers Circle: Ghettoside</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p> Los Angeles Times columnist Jill Levoy dissects what she calls the plague of murders in South Los Angeles, where black men are murdered at an astounding rate, a microcosm of a larger problem across the country. Her book, <a id="ember12263" href="/item/show/8855484081" data-add-title-link="8855484081">Ghettoside:</a> A True Story of Murder in America, is a story about a senseless murder of a young man and the relentless detective determined to find the killer. Join the Harsh Readers Circle to discuss this riveting story about urban violence. </p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: &quot;In The Game&quot;</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/a6cc0dae4cbfe62ec006e193d1b07d64/inthegame-fence-resized.jpg" alt="" style="margin: auto; display: block;">Join us for a screening of the new documentary film from Kartemquin Films, <a href="https://www.kartemquin.com/films/in-the-game/"><em>In The Game</em></a>. <span></span>This warm and often heart-tugging look at four years in the life of a girls' soccer team at Chicago's inner city Kelly High School in the Brighton Park neighborhood is an intimate study in sisterhood and hope in the face of adversity. Award-winning director Maria Finitzo (<em><a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/item/show/8319508081_5_girls">5 Girls</a>, Terra Incognita</em>) underlines the solid sense of family that young players discover in the team setting, as rocky home lives, poverty, and the political forces that dictate slashes to the school's budget conspire to limit their prospects for a bright future.  Running time: 78 minutes. The screening will be followed by a discussion.</p><span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago </a>season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: Up Heartbreak Hill</title>
        <description><![CDATA[  Film screening of <b><i data-redactor-tag="i">Up Heartbreak Hill </i></b>by <b>Erica Scharf.</b> Thomas and Tamara are track stars at their rural New Mexico high school. Like many teenagers, they are torn between the lure of brighter futures elsewhere and the ties that bind them to home. For these teens, however, home is an impoverished town on the Navajo reservation, and leaving means separating from family, tradition and the land that has been theirs for generations. <i>Up Heartbreak Hill </i>is a moving look at a new generation of Americans struggling to be both Native and modern. A co-production of Long Distance Films, Native American Public Telecommunications, ITVS, POV's Diverse Voices Project and New Mexico PBS, with funding provided by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. A co-presentation with Native American Public Telecommunications. Premiere date July 26, 2012. (60 min.) ]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>20 Moments: Chicago in the 20th Century </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img style="margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px; float: right;" alt="" src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/1bc8a8d1610a1d53427e965ff7480e5c/MaxGrinnell-sized.jpg" unselectable="on"></p>What is Chicago? What will Chicago be in the future? What has Chicago been in the recent past? These are all complex questions that fascinate Chicagoans, whether they have been here five months or fifty years. Drawing on historic photographs and visual materials from the Chicago Public Library, the Chicago History Museum, and other institutions, urbanologist <a href="http://theurbanologist.com/">Max Grinnell</a> will invite patrons into a discussion of these themes via a presentation with time for conversation and discussion afterwards.<span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives." </p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Chicago’s Public Art: Out of the Past, Into the Future </title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/1bc8a8d1610a1d53427e965ff7480e5c/MaxGrinnell-sized.jpg" alt="" style="float: right; margin: 0px 0px 10px 10px;"></p>Chicago's well-known and robust public art culture remains the envy of other major cities around the world. In this presentation, urbanologist <a href="http://theurbanologist.com/">Max Grinnell</a> will offer up some of his thoughts on the transformative qualities of Chicago's various public art initiatives, including the Percent for Art Program, the Chicago Public Art Group, and other lesser-known programs. Based on his extensive exploration of the city from O'Hare's Terminal 5 to Pullman, this program will be an engaging look into how Chicago's public art programs, formal and informal, continue to engage the interest of locals and visitors.<span></span><p>This program is part of the 2015-2016 <a href="http://www.chipublib.org/browse_program/one-book-one-chicago/">One Book, One Chicago</a> season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."</p>]]></description>
