      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: Sun Kissed</title>
        <description><![CDATA[  Film screening of <b><i data-redactor-tag="i">Sun Kissed </i></b>by <b>Maya Stark </b>and <b>Adi Lavy</b>. When a Navajo couple discovers their children have a disorder that makes exposure to sunlight fatal, they also learn their reservation is a hotbed for this rare genetic disease. Why? <i>Sun Kissed </i>follows Dorey and Yolanda Nez as they confront cultural taboos, tribal history and their own unconventional choices to learn the shocking truth: The consequences of the Navajos' Long Walk — their forced relocation by the U.S. military in 1864 — are far from over. A co-production of ITVS, with funding provided by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. A co-presentation with Native American Public Telecommunications. Premiere date October 18, 2012. (60 min.) ]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: Standing Silent Nation</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>  Film screening of <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">Standing Silent Nation </em></strong>by<strong> Suree Towfighnia </strong>and <strong>Courtney Hermann</strong>. What does a family have to endure to create a future for itself? In April 2000, Alex White Plume and his Lakota family planted industrial hemp on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota after other crops had failed. They put their hopes for a sustainable economy in hemp's hardiness and a booming worldwide demand for its many products, from clothing to food. Although growing hemp, a relative of marijuana, was banned in the U.S., Alex believed that tribal sovereignty, along with hemp's non-psychoactive properties, would protect him. But when federal agents raided the White Plumes' fields, the Lakota Nation was swept into a Byzantine struggle over tribal sovereignty, economic rights and common sense. A co-presentation of Native American Public Telecommunications. Premiere date July 3, 2007. (53 min)</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Adult Classic Book Club:  The Mayor of Casterbridge</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Thomas Hardy's <a id="ember9118" href="/item/show/1752971081" data-add-title-link="1752971081">The Mayor of Casterbridge</a> is a haunting study of guilt and lost love.  In a fit of drunken anger, Michael Henchard sells his wife and baby daughter for five guineas at a country fair.  Over the course of the following years, he manages to establish himself as a respected and prosperous pillar of the community of Casterbridge, but behind his success there always lurks the shameful secret of his past and a personality prone to self-destructive pride and temper.</p><p>Hardy is second only to Charles Dickens as the most read and most discussed writer of the Victorian era.   In terms of volume and diversity of work, Hardy is a towering literary figure with two highly respected careers — one as a novelist and one as a poet.</p><p>Copies are available at the Circulation Desk.  Please visit the branch or call (312) 744-1926 for additional information.</p>]]></description>

        <description><![CDATA[<p><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"><span class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659" data-redactor-class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659"><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/e4c1fcb65c787bd8cd628412e32553d7/Joe Kirin1.jpg" unselectable="on" alt="" style="display: block; margin: auto;"></span></span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"><span class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659" data-redactor-class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659">Croatian </span></span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"><span class="SpellingError SCX97948659" data-redactor-class="SpellingError SCX97948659">tamburitza</span></span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"> player Joe Kirin performs</span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"> music</span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"> as </span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"><span class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659" data-redactor-class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659">rich and diverse as the </span></span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"><span class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659" data-redactor-class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659">Rom (Gypsy) culture from which it was inspired. </span></span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"><span class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659" data-redactor-class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659">Experience h</span></span><span class="TextRun SCX97948659"><span class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659" data-redactor-class="NormalTextRun SCX97948659">ushed and haunting ballads to powerful, pulsating Latin rhythms.       <item>
        <title>The Absolutely True Diary Of A Part-Time Indian</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p> In <a id="ember16168" href="/item/show/2219210081" data-add-title-link="2219210081">The Absolutely True Diary of A Part-time Indian</a>, Arnold Spirit "Junior", a talented cartoonist and writer growing up on the Spokane Indian Reservation, makes a fateful decision to attend an all-white farm town high school where the only other Indian is the school mascot. He faces trouble fitting in with his white peers while he is also the target of bullies and ridicule back on the rez, adding up to a nuanced view of culture, identity, and community. Little, Brown Books For Young Readers, 2009. (Ages 12 &amp; Up)<br></p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Money Smart: Property Taxes Too High? It’s Never Too Late to Reduce Them!</title>

      <item>
        <title>Film Screening: &quot;Waking in Oak Creek&quot; and Human Rights Day Panel Discussion</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/c7b60cd618f0d7adf4aefe69b92377d0/WakingInOakCreek-resized.jpg" unselectable="on"><span></span></p><p>Join us for a screening of <a id="ember16150" href="/item/show/8897185081" data-add-title-link="8897185081">Waking in Oak Creek</a><span></span>. <em>Waking In Oak Creek</em> profiles a suburban town rocked by hate after six worshippers at a Sikh Temple are killed by a white supremacist. In the year following the attack, the film highlights a community and law enforcement working together to overcome tragedy, stand up to hate, and create a safe town for all.<br></p><p><br></p><p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/58a906d816fc499b26dcfdc8079873fa/oakcreekpanel-collage.jpg"></p><br>The screening will be followed by a panel discussion in observance of Human Rights Day, in partnership with the Chicago Commission on Human Relations. Panelists include: <p><strong>Patrice O'Neill </strong>(film producer) -  Patrice is an award-winning media producer dedicated to telling stories about everyday people transforming their communities. As co-founder of the Oakland-based non-profit strategic media production company The Working Group, she has produced successful national series on PBS for fifteen years, using a multi-platform approach that utilizes documentary film, social networking, outreach and organizing efforts to encourage dialogue and spur action.<span></span></p><p><strong>Pardeep Kaleka</strong> - Pardeep is the eldest son of Satwant Singh Kaleka – the president of the Sikh Temple of Wisconsin, who was gunned down during the attacks of August 5th, 2012. Pardeep is a first generation immigrant who grew up in Milwaukee and graduated from Marquette University. A former Milwaukee Police Officer and current educator in the inner city, Pardeep is the founder of Serve 2 Unite, a nonprofit organization is founded in response to the deaths at the temple in Oak Creek. Serve2Unite combines Art, Service Learning, and Positive Global Mentors to foster peaceful identity in schools and communities.<span></span></p><p><strong>Kalia Abiade</strong> - Kalia is the Advocacy Director at <a href="http://newcomm.org/">Center for New Community</a>. She spearheads the organization's work to equip and mobilize allied organizations and coalitions to challenge organized nativism and racism. Kalia has more than a decade of journalism experience and is the managing editor of the Center's blog Imagine 2050.<span></span></p><p><a href="http://www.preciousdavis.com/"><strong>Precious Davis</strong></a><a href="http://www.preciousdavis.com/"><strong> </strong></a>- Precious is lauded both locally and nationally as an award winning diversity professional, social justice facilitator, and performance artist. She currently is the Assistant Director of Diversity Recruitment Initiatives at Columbia College Chicago , her alma mater from which she received a BA in Liberal Arts. Precious currently implements and oversees the Campus Wide Diversity Initiative and is the first woman of color to hold this position. She recently was awarded the prestigious "30 under 30" award from The Windy City Times and included in the 2014 Trans 100 list. <span></span></p><p><strong>Sargent Lori Cooper</strong> of the Chicago Police Department - Lori joined the Chicago Police Department in 1992 and from the academy was assigned to the 23rd District on the North Side of Chicago. By 1994 she was working as a community resource officer and began to recognize incidents of hate crimes committed against the LGBT community. In 1996 she was named the district LGBT liaison and in 1998 became the city wide liaison and was assigned as a Civil Rights Hate Crimes Investigator. Cooper became an educator nationally on the importance of positive relationships between the LGBT community and the police Community, advocating for all departments to establish LGBT liaisons. In 2005, Lori Cooper was promoted to Sergeant and following several years in the patrol division, returned to become the Commanding Officer of the Special Activities Section which includes the Civil Rights Hate Crimes Unit<span></span><br></p><p>Seating in the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium is first come, first served, limit of 385.<br></p><p>This program is presented as part of <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org">One Book, One Chicago</a>'s 2015-2016 season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."  This program is a partnership with the <a href="http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/cchr.html">Chicago Commission on Human Relations.</a></p><br>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f07fa516760c7d5202c6af</link>
        <guid>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/55f07fa516760c7d5202c6af</guid>                <bc:start_date>2015-12-11T00:00:00Z</bc:start_date>
        <bc:end_date>2015-12-11T02:00:00Z</bc:end_date>

        <title>Fairy Tale Story Dance</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Tiffany Lawson Dance will present music and movement fairy tale program for small children with big imaginations.       <item>
        <title>&quot;Soulful Perspectives&quot; Adult Book Discussion</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Join us for a lively discussion of<em> <a id="ember10721" href="/item/show/8896710081" data-add-title-link="8896710081">The Third Coast</a> </em>by <a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?q=%22Dyja%2C+Tom%22&amp;search_category=author&amp;t=author">Tom Dyja</a>. Much of what defined the nation as it grew into a superpower was produced in Chicago. Before air travel overtook trains, nearly every coast-to coast journey included a stop there, and this flow of people and commodities made Chicago America's central clearinghouse, laboratory and factory. Chicago native Thomas Dyja recreates the story of the city in its postwar prime and explains its profound impact on modern America. Come and bring a friend!  Light refreshments provided.</p>]]></description>

        <title>Harsh Readers Circle: Louis Armstrong</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Louis Armstrong was the founding father of jazz and one of this century's towering cultural figures. The musical talents of Satchmo - as Armstrong became universally known - were prodigious and groundbreaking. Author <a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?q=%22Bergreen%2C+Laurence%22&amp;search_category=author&amp;t=author">Lawrence Bergreen</a> offers a comprehensive and substantial biography of this talented musician in <a id="ember2426" href="/item/show/1402064081" data-add-title-link="1402064081">Louis Armstrong:</a> An Extravagant Life.       <item>
        <title>Harsh Readers Circle: Hair Story</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Join the Harsh Readers Circle for a discussion of <a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?&amp;t=author&amp;search_category=author&amp;q=Byrd%2C%20Ayana%20D%20">Ayana D. Byrd</a> and <a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?&amp;t=author&amp;search_category=author&amp;q=Lori%20L.%20Tharps'%20">Lori L. Tharps'</a> book on   the culture behind the ever-changing state of Black hair-from fifteenth century Africa to the present-day United States. <a id="ember4428" href="/item/show/8759784081" data-add-title-link="8759784081">Hair Story:</a> Untangling the Roots of Black Hair in America explains to readers that the hair we grow and the styles we wear it in say something significant about who we are, where we've come from and where we hope to go.   While many realize that when it comes to black hair, there is much, much more historical and cultural significance than meets the eye. It takes a deep study like this one, however, to reveal what our hair says about ourselves and our society.</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Harsh Readers Circle: America&#39;s Mistress</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Eartha Kitt was the daughter of a black woman and a white man at a time when white women dominated the airwaves. She was undeniably attractive, but not conventionally beautiful. Kitt wasn't a particularly gifted singer, but she had her own immediately identifiable sound. What made her famous was a persona that radiated what we would today call "attitude." Author John L. Williams offers readers a fast-paced, well-written and exhaustively researched book with <a id="ember6437" href="/item/show/8829309081" data-add-title-link="8829309081">America's Mistress</a>: The Life and Times of Eartha Kitt. Join the Harsh Readers Circle for a discussion of this exciting biography. <br></p><p><br></p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/555a29457b253bb0780155b2</link>

      <item>
        <title>Author and Kiva co-founder Jessica Jackley</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p><img src="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/uploads/images/full/58d15fc045496f9e27e26b39897e3874/JessicaJackley-resized.jpg" unselectable="on"></p><p> <strong><em data-redactor-tag="em">Please note this event was originally scheduled for November 12, 2015 and has been moved to this date, March 22, 2016.</em></strong></p><p>Kiva co-founder Jessica Jackley, author of <a id="ember2631" href="/item/show/8889521081" data-add-title-link="8889521081">Clay, Water, Brick</a>, shares her personal story of co-creating this tool for social change and the evolution of this nonprofit that started in a modest off-campus Stanford apartment and went on to become a global movement. With candor and warmth, she highlights the business, and more importantly, life lessons she learned first-hand from the entrepreneurs themselves, many of them in the world's poorest countries.<span></span></p><p>Seating in the Cindy Pritzker Auditorium is first come, first served, limit of 385. Books will be available for sale, and the author will sign books at the conclusion of the program.<br></p><p>This program is presented as part of <a href="http://www.onebookonechicago.org/">One Book, One Chicago</a>'s 2015-2016 season, exploring the theme of "Chicago: The City That Gives."</p>]]></description>

      <item>
        <title>Harsh Research Collection: Gateway to Freedom</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>Author <a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?q=%22Foner%2C+Eric%22&amp;search_category=author&amp;t=author">Eric Foner</a>, Pulitzer Prize winner and history professor at Columbia University, offers a new story that will surprise most readers. A big surprise in <a id="ember8287" href="/item/show/8855445081" data-add-title-link="8855445081">Gateway to Freedom</a><em>: </em>The Hidden History of the Underground Railroad's<em> </em>is that, despite the book's subtitle, the Underground Railroad often was not hidden at all. People boldly helped raise money for the "Railroad" and hid runaway slaves. <span class="drop-cap">F</span><span class="smallcaps">oner's compelling narrative </span>centers on New York City, another un&shy;expected twist. Unlike Boston and Philadelphia, with their deep-rooted reformist traditions—&shy;and unlike such upstate cities as Buffalo and Syracuse—the metropolis was hardly known for abolitionist fervor. Building on fresh evidence including a detailed record of slave escapes secretly kept by Sydney Howard Gay, one of the key organizers in New York Foner elevates the underground railroad from folklore to detailed history. The story is inspiring full of memorable characters making their first appearance on the historical stage. It eventually took a civil war to destroy American slavery, but here at last is the story of the courageous effort to fight slavery by "practical abolition." Join the Harsh Readers Circle for a thoughtful discussion of this work.</p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/555a2b1b7b253bb078015635</link>
        <guid>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/555a2b1b7b253bb078015635</guid>                <bc:start_date>2016-04-16T19:00:00Z</bc:start_date>

      <item>
        <title>Harsh Readers Circle: The GQ Candidate</title>
        <description><![CDATA[<p>"<a id="ember10137" href="/item/show/8553711081" data-add-title-link="8553711081">The GQ Candidate</a><em></em> gives readers a behind-the-scenes look at what happens in the lives of candidates, and the people closest to them, when the cameras aren't rolling. In addition to the story of the campaign, the novel also follows the lives of Luke's tight knit circle of friends and reveals how his amazing race changes their lives forever." -Goodreads</p><p>Join the Harsh Readers Circle for a discussion of political analyst <a href="https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/search?&amp;t=author&amp;search_category=author&amp;q=Goff%2C%20Keli%20">Keli Geoff's</a> debut novel about a  charismatic African American/Jewish governor who runs for President of the United States. This entertaining novel is full of scandal and intrigue. </p>]]></description>
        <link>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/555a2b557b253bb07801563a</link>
        <guid>https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/555a2b557b253bb07801563a</guid>                <bc:start_date>2016-05-21T19:00:00Z</bc:start_date>

        <bc:is_cancelled>false</bc:is_cancelled>
        <bc:is_featured>false</bc:is_featured>
        <bc:is_featured_at_location>false</bc:is_featured_at_location>
        <category domain="Type">Book Clubs</category><category domain="Audience">Adults</category><category domain="Language">English</category>
          <bc:location>
            <bc:name>Woodson Regional</bc:name>
            <bc:latitude>41.720915</bc:latitude><bc:longitude>-87.642915</bc:longitude><bc:number>9525</bc:number><bc:street>S.
